Award.AwardTitle: The Dynamics of Political Choice: the Third Module of the Comparative Study of Electoral Systems (CSES)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
There has been a significant increase in the number of democratic nations over the last two decades. The Comparative Study of Electoral Systems (CSES) project is especially well-positioned to study this wave of democratization. The current project seeks support to complete the activities of the third module of the CSES, and to plan and design the fourth module. The project encompasses the coordination and leadership of the social science research efforts of approximately 60 nations.

Now over ten years old, the CSES is a systematic cross-national study of comparative electoral behavior. Theoretically informed, the project has the potential to transform the study of comparative politics; it has become accepted as one of the principal resources for scholars investigating cross-national public-opinion and political-behavioral research. Involving the collaboration of more than 200 scholars, CSES advances the understanding of enduring and fundamental questions about electoral choice in ways not otherwise possible. CSES coordinates the operation of approximately 60 national election studies across the world, thereby ensuring that information about citizens' behavior and attitudes gathered at each site is comparable. The goals of this unique research program are: to illuminate how societal, political, and economic institutional and structural contexts, most especially electoral institutions, shape the beliefs and behaviors of citizens and condition the nature and quality of democratic choice as expressed through popular elections; to understand the nature of political and social divisions and alignments; and to shed light on how citizens living under diverse political arrangements evaluate democratic institutions and processes.

The CSES has broader impacts for both the academic and policymaking community. In addition to the survey data, information about the institutional arrangements and other social-, political-, and economic-contextual conditions that characterize each participating country are also collected, again in comparable form. CSES designs, receives, rationalizes, cleans and checks, and merges all of these data, and then makes them freely and immediately available to the world's scholarly community via the project website at: http://www.cses.org. This public-use facility is a resource for comparative researchers worldwide, and that is reflected in the large and growing number of publications that utilize the data.

Only through the kind of comparative analysis that CSES makes possible, where comparable samples of citizens are observed with comparable instruments under different institutional settings, can the impact of institutions be properly ascertained and measured. And only through genuinely comparative analysis can the merits and shortcomings of different democratic arrangements be discovered. The output from the CSES has policy implications for the design and implementation of electoral systems around the world, as well as implications for the normative study of democracy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In existence since 1994, the Comparative Study of Electoral Systems (CSES) project is a collaborative effort among election study teams from more than 60 countries around the world.  The study is developed and implemented by an international committee of leading scholars of electoral politics and political science. All datasets that the CSES project produces are made available to the public at no cost on the project website (www.cses.org). 

Participating countries include a common set of questions in surveys of individuals who are eligible to vote.  The surveys are conducted soon after national elections in each country. The participating countries include these additional questions in their surveys at no cost to the CSES project itself.  The CSES project then merges the survey responses with information about the broader electoral system and political environment in each country.  This design enables scientists to examine how different electoral systems and political environments in each country impact the behaviors and attitudes of the individuals eligible to vote there. 

While there are many scientific questions that CSES datasets can be used to address, the project is designed with a special focus on understanding why and how voters choose to vote.  Every five years, the CSES project changes some of its survey questions in order to help investigate new scientific issues that would benefit from the project's unique research design and worldwide participation. For example, the dataset for the third module of CSES was collected from 2006 through 2011 and is intended to help understand how voters respond to having more or less choice in elections.  By "more or less choice" we mean whether voters feel they have enough meaningful options available to choose among or not, and how well or not those options meet their individual preferences and needs. If eligible voters feel they do not have enough choice in an election, how will they react?  Will they not show up to vote at all?  Will they become less interested in the political process?  Will this stimulate the formation of new political parties that better represent the interests of the voters? 

The CSES project is focused on collecting its datasets in the highest quality way possible and providing the resulting datasets as a public good. Analysis of the third module of CSES is currently underway. Thousands of scholars, students, policymakers, journalists, and others from around the world are using data from CSES to investigate not only the above issues, but numerous other topics related to elections and political science. For more information about the hundreds of presentations and publications that have benefitted from CSES data, we encourage visiting the bibliography that is maintained on the project website.
